verses.text: A man from the house of Levi went and took a daughter of Levi as his wife.
verses.comment: Retains the original emphasis on tribe; ‘house of Levi’ means from the Levites; cf. Ex. 6:20 for identification.

verses.text: The woman conceived and bore a son; and when she saw that he was a beautiful child, she hid him for three months.
verses.comment: ‘Beautiful’ may also mean ‘goodly’ or ‘fine’; cf. Heb. 11:23.

verses.text: When she could no longer hide him, she took a papyrus basket, coated it with tar and pitch, placed the child inside, and put it among the reeds by the riverbank.
verses.comment: ‘Papyrus basket’ literally ‘ark’; kept as ‘basket’ for clarity. ‘Tar and pitch’ matches the original meaning.

verses.text: His sister stood at a distance to see what would happen to him.
verses.comment: The sister is Miriam (cf. Ex. 15:20), though not named here.

verses.text: Pharaoh’s daughter came down to bathe at the river, while her maidens walked along the riverbank. She saw the basket among the reeds and sent her servant girl to get it.
verses.comment: ‘Servant girl’ replaces ambiguous ‘maid’ with accurate English for context.

verses.text: When she opened it, she saw the child, and the baby was crying. She took pity on him and said, “This is one of the Hebrews’ children.”
verses.comment: Retains ‘Hebrews’—ethnicity is important.

verses.text: Then his sister said to Pharaoh’s daughter, 'Should I go and call a nurse from the Hebrew women to nurse the child for you?'
verses.comment: ‘Nurse from the Hebrew women’ matches Hebrew text.

verses.text: Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Go.” So, the girl went and called the child’s mother.
verses.comment: ‘Go’ is direct speech from Pharaoh’s daughter; roles clarified.

verses.text: Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Take this child away and nurse him for me, and I will pay you.” So the woman took the child and nursed him.
verses.comment: ‘Pay you’ clarifies ‘wages’ from original.

verses.text: When the child grew older, she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. She named him Moses, saying, “Because I drew him out of the water.”
verses.comment: ‘Moses’—a wordplay from ‘draw out’. Preserved in text.

verses.text: It happened in those days, when Moses had grown up, that he went out to his people and saw their forced labor. He saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his brothers.
verses.comment: ‘His brothers’ interprets ‘from his brethren’ for clarity.

verses.text: He looked this way and that, and when he saw no one, he struck down the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
verses.comment: ‘Struck down’ is literal for killed, avoids euphemism.

verses.text: He went out the next day, and behold, two Hebrews were fighting. He said to the one who was in the wrong, “Why are you hitting your companion?”
verses.comment: Clarifies ‘his companion’ for idiomatic meaning.

verses.text: He answered, 'Who made you a ruler and judge over us? Are you planning to kill me as you killed the Egyptian?' Then Moses was afraid and thought, 'Surely what I did is known.'
verses.comment: Retains direct speech style; cf. Acts 7:27-29 for further reflection.

verses.text: When Pharaoh heard about this, he sought to kill Moses. But Moses fled from Pharaoh and stayed in the land of Midian. He sat down by a well.
verses.comment: ‘Sat down by a well’ emphasizes geography.

verses.text: Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters, and they came and drew water, and filled the troughs to water their father’s flock.
verses.comment: ‘Filled the troughs’ details the process.

verses.text: Then some shepherds came and drove them away, but Moses rose up and defended them and watered their flock.
verses.comment: ‘Defended them’ is literal and preserves action.

verses.text: When they returned to their father Reuel, he said, 'How is it that you have come home so soon today?'
verses.comment: ‘Reuel’ is kept from Hebrew text, cf. Num. 10:29.

verses.text: They said, 'An Egyptian rescued us from the shepherds, and he even drew water for us and watered the flock.'
verses.comment: ‘An Egyptian’—Moses’ presumed identity.

verses.text: He said to his daughters, 'Where is he? Why did you leave the man? Call him, that he may eat bread.'
verses.comment: ‘Eat bread’ is idiomatic for sharing a meal.

verses.text: Moses agreed to stay with the man, and he gave Moses his daughter Zipporah in marriage.
verses.comment: ‘Stay with’ keeps original verb sense.

verses.text: She bore a son, and he named him Gershom, saying, 'I have been a stranger in a foreign land.'
verses.comment: Name ‘Gershom’ explained with meaning note.

verses.text: Now it came to pass in those days that the king of Egypt died, but the Israelites groaned because of their slavery and cried out, and their cry for help went up to God because of their bondage.
verses.comment: ‘Bondage’ matches original; ‘cry for help’ is deliberate.

verses.text: God heard their groaning and remembered His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
verses.comment: ‘Remembered His covenant’ is literal in Hebrew, denotes action to fulfill, not forgetfulness.

verses.text: God looked upon the Israelites and took notice of them.
verses.comment: ‘Took notice’ renders ‘knew’ from original; this implies God’s care and intention to act.
